body: I'm interested in this bug, and I'm looking into it.

I found the bahavior [here ](https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/df85cd3354d101b99d4264682e7bbb2fbaf2a6ad/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/recursive/comparison/RecursiveComparisonDifferenceCalculator.java#L137)is unexpected. `dualValuesToCompare` dose not remove `visitedDualValues`, which causes the infinite recursion.

Hi @joel-costigliola and @darkliang  - thanks for your swift feedback.

You say:
> the solution is to avoid treating Path as an Iterable.

I assume this is within AssertJ ?

Yes, in AssertJ recursive comparison.

In the meantime, you can [register a specific comparator](https://assertj.github.io/doc/#assertj-core-recursive-comparison-comparators) for Path (just calling the regular Path comparator) as they take precedence in the recursive comparison, or you can wait for 3.16.0 which I hope to release in a week ;-)
So, do we need to treat Path as an uniterable field by default? @joel-costigliola
Yes but just for the recursive comparison.

Abouth `Path` as iterable, we used a similar approach in `containsOnlyKeys:` https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/1b638aa55aa7bc0e9c807d9c67f4f3d6742ef630/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/AbstractMapAssert.java#L1152-L1161
This issue is still present in 3.19.0?
@Brummolix this should have been fixed with c5de8911ec51415fb7d20f53f5c99ee6a7fde150. Are you still facing the same issue with 3.19.0?
